evidence.text: Plaintiffs have a non-statutory right of action to enjoin and declare unlawful official action that is ultra vires and in excess of legal authority

evidence.text: Plaintiffs: Mary Boyle, Alexander Hoehn‑Saric, Richard Trumka Jr.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Congress enacted the Consumer Product Safety Act (CPSA), Pub. L. No. 92‑573, 86 Stat. 1207, in 1972 to protect the public against unreasonable risks of injury... President Trump’s purported removal of Plaintiffs from their Commissioner roles violates the CPSA because the removals are not based on neglect of duty or malfeasance in office

extracted.value: Congress enacted the Consumer Product Safety Act (CPSA) establishing the CPSC; President Trump purportedly terminated Commissioners without statutory authority; Plaintiffs were confirmed under statutory removal conditions; removal violated 15 U.S.C. §2053(a) and implied constitutional duties; Plaintiffs faced loss of pay, benefits, and ability to serve; defendants obstructed Plaintiffs’ duties

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Declare that Defendants’ removal of Plaintiffs from their roles as CPSC Commissioners was unlawful and that Plaintiffs are entitled to continue serving out their terms as CPSC Commissioners

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Enjoin Defendant Feldman from obstructing Plaintiffs ...; Enjoin Defendants Bessent, Vought, and Feldman from depriving Plaintiffs of the pay and benefits

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Award Plaintiffs their costs and attorneys’ fees

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: remove Commissioners only “for neglect of duty or malfeasance in office but for no other cause.” 15 U.S.C. § 2053(a)

evidence.text: Article II of the U.S. Constitution requires the President to “take Care that the Laws be faithfully executed.” U.S. Const. art. II, § 3
